main-text.text: State Capitol P.O. Box 2062 Albany, NY 12220-0062 www.its.ny.gov
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 1.0 Purpose and Benefits
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Encryption is a cryptographic operation that is used to enhance security and protect the State's electronic data ("data") by transforming readable information ("plaintext") into unintelligible information ("ciphertext"). Encryption is an effective tool in mitigating the threat of unauthorized access to data.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 2.0 Authority
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Section 103(10) of the State Technology Law provides the Office of Information Technology Services (ITS) with the authority to establish statewide technology policies, including technology and security standards. Section 2 of Executive Order No. 117, established January 2002, provides the State Chief Information Officer with the authority to oversee, direct and coordinate the establishment of information technology policies, protocols and standards for State government, including hardware, software, security and business re-engineering. Details regarding this authority can be found in NYS ITS Policy, NYS-P08-002 Authority to Establish Enterprise Information Technology (IT) Policies, Standards and Guidelines.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 3.0 Scope
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: This standard applies to all "State Entities" (SE), defined as "State Government" entities as defined in Executive Order 117, established January 2002, or "State Agencies" as defined in Section 101 of the State Technology Law. This includes employees and all third parties (such as local governments, consultants, vendors, and contractors) that use or access any ITS resource for which ITS the SE has administrative responsibility,
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: including systems managed or hosted by third parties on behalf of the ITS SE. While an SE may adopt a different standard, it must include the requirements in this one.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: This standard applies to all systems, which includes websites and web services, for which the SE has administrative responsibility, including those managed and hosted by third parties on behalf of the State.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 4.0 Information Statement
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: The need for encryption of information is based on its classification, risk assessment results, and use case.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Attention must be given to the regulations and national restrictions (e.g., export controls) that may apply to the use of cryptographic techniques in different parts of the world. The US Government restricts the export, disclosure, or release of encryption technologies to foreign countries or foreign nationals, including "deemed exports" to foreign nationals within the United States (excluding those foreign nationals with permanent resident visas (e.g., Green Cards), US citizenship, or 'protected person' status). If you have any questions, please contact Counsel and Legal Services.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Encryption products for confidentiality of data at rest and data in transit must incorporate Federal Information Processing Standard (FIPS) approved algorithms for data encryption. Approved encryption algorithms are contained in Appendix A.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Hashing algorithms transform a digital message into a short representation for use in digital signatures and other applications to validate the integrity of the message. Although a hash function, such as SHA 1, provides a certain amount of security strength, it does not meet all security requirements for keyed-hash functions such as HMAC SHA 1. Refer to FIPS 180-4 Secure Hash Standard (SHS) for more information on different types of application hashing algorithms as well as Appendix A.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Hashing algorithms can be used for multiple purposes including, but not limited to, digital signatures, message authentication codes, key derivation functions, and pseudo random functions. Approved hashing functions are contained in Appendix A.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: The use of outdated, cryptographically broken, proprietary encryption algorithms or hashing functions is prohibited. Due to the prevalence of incorrectly implemented cryptography, encryption products must have FIPS 140-3 Security Requirements for Cryptographic Modules validation and be operated in FIPS mode. Refer to Appendix B Guidance in Selecting FIPS 140 Validated Products for further information.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Electronic information used to authenticate the identity of an individual or process (e.g., PIN, password, passphrase) must be encrypted when stored, transported, or transmitted. This does not include the distribution of a one-time use PIN, password, passphrase, token code, etc., provided it is not distributed along with any other authentication information (e.g., user-ID).
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Page 2 of 6
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: A system's security plan must include documentation to show appropriate review of encryption methodologies and products. This will demonstrate due diligence in choosing a method or product that has received substantial positive review by reputable third-party analysts.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 4.1 Data in Transit
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Encryption is required for data in transit when
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: · Electronic Personal, Private, or Sensitive Information (PPSI) is transmitted (including, but not limited to, e-mail, File Transfer Protocol (FTP), instant messaging, e-fax, Voice Over Internet Protocol (VoIP), etc.).
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: · Encryption of data in transit is prescribed by law or regulation.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: · Connecting to the State internal network(s) over a wireless network.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: · Remotely accessing the State internal network(s) or devices over a shared (e.g., Internet) or personal (e.g., Bluetooth, infrared) network. This does not apply to remote access over a State managed point to point dedicated connection.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: · Data is being transmitted with a State public-facing website or web services (Hypertext Transfer Protocol Secure (HTTPS) must be used in lieu of Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP) where technically possible). State public-facing websites must use HTTP Strict Transport Security (HSTS), automatically redirecting HTTP requests to HTTPS websites where technically possible. See minimum browser support listed in Appendix C.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: Appropriate encryption methods for data in transit include, but are not limited to, Transport Layer Security (TLS) 1.2 or later, Secure Shell (SSH) 2.0 or later, Wi-Fi Protected Access (WPA) version 2 or later (with WiFi Protected Setup disabled) and encrypted Virtual Private Networks (VPNs). Components should be configured to support the strongest cipher suites possible. Ciphers that are not compliant with this standard must be disabled.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 4.2 Data at Rest
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Encryption is required for data at rest when
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: · Desktops access or contain State Entity (SE) PPSI.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: · Data stores (including, but not limited to, databases, file shares) contain SE PPSI.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: · Mobile devices, whether State issued or third-party, access or contain any SE information.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: · Portable storage devices contain any SE information.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: · Electronic PPSI is transported or stored outside of a State facility.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: Full disk encryption is required for all State issued laptops that access or contain SE information. Full disk encryption products must use either pre-boot authentication that
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Page 3 of 6
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: utilizes the device's Trusted Platform Module (TPM), or Unified Extensible Firmware Interface (UEFI) Secure Boot.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: To mitigate attacks against encryption keys, when outside of State facilities, SE laptops and third-party laptops that access or contain SE PPSI must be powered down (i.e., shut down or hibernated) when unattended.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: SEs must have a process or procedure in place for confirming devices and media have been successfully encrypted using at least one of the following, listed in preferred order:
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 1. automated policy enforcement
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: 2. automated inventory system
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: 3. manual record keeping
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: 4.3 Key Management
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: The SE must ensure that a secure environment is established to protect the cryptographic keys used to encrypt and decrypt information.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: · Keys must be securely distributed and stored.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: · Unencrypted keys must not be stored with the data that they encrypt.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: Access to keys must be restricted to only individuals who have a business need to access the keys.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: Keys will be protected with an authentication token that conforms to the identified assurance level as per the NYS-P20-001 Digital Identity Policy.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: Compromise of a cryptographic key would cause all information encrypted with that key to be considered unencrypted. If a compromise has been discovered, a new key must be generated and used to continue protection of the encrypted information. Specific circumstances should be evaluated to determine if a breach notification is required.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Encryption keys and their associated software products must be maintained for the life of the archived data that was encrypted with that product.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 5.0 Compliance
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: This standard shall take effect upon publication. Compliance is expected with all enterprise policies and standards. ITS may amend its policies and standards at any time; compliance with amended policies and standards is expected.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: If compliance with this standard is not feasible or technically possible, or if deviation from this policy is necessary to support a business function, State Entities shall request an exception through the Chief Information Security Office exception process.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Page 4 of 6
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: 6.0 Definitions of Key Terms
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Except for terms defined in this policy, all terms shall have the meanings found in http://www.its.ny.gov/glossary.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 7.0 Contact Information
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Submit all inquiries and requests for future enhancements to the policy owner at:
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Chief Information Security Office Reference: NYS-S14-007 NYS Office of Information Technology Services 1220 Washington Avenue, Building 5 Albany, NY 12226 Telephone: (518) 242-5200
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Email: CISO@its.ny.gov
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Statewide technology policies, standards, and guidelines may be found at the following website: http://www.its.ny.gov/tables/technologypolicyindex
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 8.0 Revision History
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: This policy document should be reviewed consistent with the requirements set forth in NYS-P09-003 Process for Establishing Information Technology Policies, Standards, and Guidelines
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Page 5 of 6
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: 9.0 Related Documents
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: NIST Special Publication 800-111, Guide To Storage Encryption Technologies For End User Devices
main-text.name: Text

main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: NIST Special Publication 800-57, Part 1, Recommendation for Key Management - Part 1: General
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: NIST Federal Information Processing Standard (FIPS) Publication 140-3
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: NIST Federal Information Processing Standard (FIPS) Publication 198-1
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: NIST Federal Information Processing Standard (FIPS) Publication 180-4
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: NIST Special Publication 800-107, Revision 1, Recommendation for Applications Using Approved Hash Algorithms
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Page 6 of 6
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: APPENDIX A - Approved Algorithms
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: NYS-S14-007 - Appendix A
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: Page 1 of 1
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: APPENDIX B - Guidance for Selecting FIPS 140 Validated Products
main-text.name: Page-header

main-text.text: All government agencies that use cryptographic-based systems to protect Personal, Private or Sensitive Information (PPSI), need to have a minimum level of assurance that the product's stated security claim is valid.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: On July 17, 1995, the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) established the Cryptographic Module Validation Program (CMVP) that validates cryptographic modules to Federal Information Processing Standards (FIPS) cryptography-based standards.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Historically, over 48% of cryptographic modules that have undergone FIPS validation had security flaws that were corrected during testing. In other words, without validation, users would have had only a 50-50 chance of buying correctly implemented cryptography.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: The list of FIPS validated cryptographic modules can be found on the NIST web site at http://csrc.nist.gov/groups/STM/cmvp/validation.html. The list can be searched by vendor or by year of validation.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: It is important to note that the items on this list are cryptographic modules which may either be an embedded component of a product or application, or a complete product in and of itself. In addition, it is possible that vendors who are not found on this list might incorporate a validated cryptographic module from this list into their own products and components.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: When selecting a product from a vendor, verify that the application or product that is being offered is either a validated cryptographic module itself (e.g., full disk encryption solution, SmartCard) or the application or product uses an embedded validated cryptographic module (toolkit, etc.) by confirming the module's validation certificate number. Ask the vendor to supply a signed letter stating their application, product or module is a validated module or incorporates a validated module which provides all the cryptographic services in the solution and references the module's validation certificate number. This number can be checked against the CMVP validation list. If the information does not agree, the vendor is not offering a validated solution.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Be aware that vendors may sometimes make invalid conformance claims such as:
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: · The module has been designed for compliance to FIPS 140-3.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: · The module has been pre-validated and is on the CMVP pre-validation list.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: · The module will be submitted for testing.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: · The module has been independently reviewed and tested to comply with FIPS 140-3.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: · The module meets all the requirements of FIPS 140-3.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: · The module implements FIPS Approved algorithms; including having algorithm certificates.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: · The module follows the guidelines detailed in FIPS 140-3.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: A cryptographic module does not meet the requirements or conform to the FIPS standard unless a reference can be made to the validation certificate number.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: NYS-S14-007 - Appendix B
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: Page 1 of 2
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: Users must also be cognizant of the version number of the validated cryptographic module and, for software products, the operating systems that it has been tested on. Only the version numbers listed in the Cryptographic Module column of the CMVP list are FIPS validated and only when run on the operating systems listed in the Level or Description column.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: FIPS Mode
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Many validated products have the capability to operate in FIPS mode, as well as non-FIPS mode. Operating in FIPS mode will ensure that the module uses only FIPS approved encryption algorithms.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Vendors provide a "Security Policy" as part of their module or product validation. This "Security Policy" can be found under the Cryptographic Module column on the CMVP list. The "Security Policy" will provide information on how to configure the module in a FIPS mode of operation and how the module functions to meet the FIPS requirements.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Modules in Process
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: NIST maintains a Modules in Process list. Inclusion on the list is at the option of the vendor. Posting on this list does not imply a guarantee of final FIPS validation. Therefore, SEs that deploy a module before it is validated incur a level of risk in that the module may never be validated, or the version submitted for testing is not the version that is validated.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: NYS-S14-007 - Appendix B
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: Page 2 of 2
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: APPENDIX € Minimum Browser Support
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: NYS-S14-007 Appendix €

data.text: New York State Information Technology Standard
Issued By:  NYS Office of Information  Technology Services
Original Standard Release;  replaces  CSCIC/OCS Cryptographic Controls (S10-006)  and Key Management Standards (S10-007)  and ITS Encryption Standard (ITS-S07-001)
Thomas Smith,  Chief Information  Security Officer

Allow for UEFI Secure Boot in place of pre- boot authentication. Require TPM for pre-boot  authentication. Minor wording clarifications.  Updated key length for ECDSA and SHA from  224 to 256 in Appendix A.
Deborah A.  Snyder, Deputy  Chief Information  Security Officer
Require all websites and web services within  scope to be accessible through a secure  connection (HTTPS). Revised TLS 1.1 to 1.2
Deborah A.  Snyder, Deputy  Chief Information  Security Officer
Update to Scope, contact information and  rebranding
Deborah A.  Snyder, Deputy  Chief Information  Security Officer
Add Appendix C - Minimum Browser Support
Deborah A.  Snyder, Acting  Chief Information  Security Officer
Update revised Scope and Authority and  update links from Identity Assurance to Digital  Identity
Karen Sorady,  Chief Information  Security Officer
Karen Sorady,  Chief Information  Security Officer
Edge 13 for Windows 10 Mobile v1511 or higher
None No support for Windows Phone 8.1 or below
